```{r}

Typical_Employee_Survey_Data <- read.csv("Typical_Employee_Survey_Data.csv")
job <- data.frame(Typical_Employee_Survey_Data)

dim(job)
col(job)
ncol(job)
nrow(job)
colnames(job)
colnames(job[,sapply(job,is.numeric)])

#1. Print out the 5-point summary and boxplot (numerical columns) for each column (20 points)

num_cols <- names(job)[sapply(job, is.numeric)]

for (nm in num_cols) {
  cat("\n### Five-number summary for:", nm, "\n")
  print(stats::fivenum(job[[nm]], na.rm = TRUE))
}

for (nm in num_cols) {
  boxplot(job[[nm]])
}


#2. Convert the columns that need to be converted to Factors (20 points)

job$gender <- as.factor(job$gender)
job$JobSatisfaction <- as.factor(job$JobSatisfaction)
job$impJobCharacterstics <- as.factor(job$impJobCharacterstics)
job$DecisionAuthority <- as.factor(job$DecisionAuthority)
job$BudgetDecisions <- as.factor(job$BudgetDecisions)
job$Proud <- as.factor(job$Proud)
job$stay <- as.factor(job$stay)
job$relations <- as.factor(job$relations)

#3. Plot the right visual for each column (20 points)
hist(job$age, main="Histogram: age", xlab="age")
hist(job$YearsInJob, main="Histogram: YearsInJob", xlab="YearsInJob")
hist(job$Promotions, main="Histogram: Promotions", xlab="Promotions")

barplot(table(job$gender))
barplot(table(job$JobSatisfaction))
barplot(table(job$impJobCharacterstics))
barplot(table(job$DecisionAuthority))
barplot(table(job$BudgetDecisions))
barplot(table(job$Proud))
barplot(table(job$stay))
barplot(table(job$relations))


#4. Plot scatter plots to show few relationships (20 points)
plot(job$age, job$YearsInJob)
plot(job$age, job$Promotions)
plot(job$YearsInJob, job$Promotions)
```
